The most important political deadline of the decade is coming up in just a few weeks, and a key source in the House has told
that the Democrats are all but assured to drop the ball on it, dooming their electoral prospects for years to come.

A source in the House has confirmed that Democrats are likely going to let pass the most important political deadline of the decade — and the consequences promise to be dire.

that Democrats have until August 16, or shortly thereafter, to pass redistricting reform. That’s the date when the U.S. Census Bureau will release census data to the states, enabling them to begin the once-a-decade process of redrawing their state legislative and congressional districts.
in which state legislatures draw those districts are Republican-controlled. If no reform is passed, the GOP is planning to use the process to disempower Democratic voters for ten years.

Democrats made election reform their first priority in Congress this year with an ambitious piece of legislation known as the For The People Act, alternatively known as H.R.1 and S.1, which contains redistricting reforms. But as the pivotal August 16 deadline approaches, Biden and party leadership appear to have given up on the issue completely.
“We just passed an independent redistricting commission [in H.R.1] to ensure that Republicans don’t draw the lines and secure a majority with a minority of the national vote,” the House source told
. “It would be political malpractice for Democrats not to do this when we have the majority.”

And yet, that’s exactly what appears to be happening, the source explained: “Unfortunately redistricting reform is unlikely to happen, given the president’s unwillingness to push for doing away with the filibuster for democracy reform.”

Weeks after a Republican filibuster prevented debate on the For The People Act, Biden gave a speech at the National Constitution Center in Philadelphia in which he declined to back filibuster reform — which is currently held up by two Democratic senators — and encouraged his audience to think of alternative means to combat voter suppression.

The last time districts were redrawn, the GOP planned ahead and invested heavily in state races to solidify control of state legislatures. They then weaponized the map-drawing process, crafting districts that heavily favored the GOP. The result? Republican majorities that were able to withstand Democatic wave elections. The GOP held the House until 2018, dooming the Obama administration’s agenda. Republicans have held a majority of state governments ever since.
Thanks to better map-drawing technologies and
that cleared the way for continued partisan redistricting, experts say the current round of gerrymandering is likely to be far more extreme.
Last week, Rep. Ronny Jackson, R-Texas,
admitted to a conference of religious conservatives
that the GOP plan is to gerrymander control of the House.
“We have redistricting coming up and the Republicans control most of that process in most of the states around the country,” Jackson said. “That alone should get us the majority back.”
Meanwhile, Congress is set to go on recess soon for most of August.

had just been released, and Instagram didn’t exist yet.
Today, the federal minimum wage is still $7.25.

Texas oil giant Apache Corp. appears

— or rather, injustice. In 2013, a paralegal sued company in Texas for age and gender discrimination. A jury sided with the plaintiff, awarding her and her team $900,000. An appeals court upheld the decision, and the Texas Supreme Court declined to hear the case. Litigants are permitted to ask the state’s justices to reconsider such decisions, but the court rarely does so. In this case, Apache Corp. filed such a request, but only after donating $250,000 to the reelection of two of the court’s incumbent justices. This week, the court sided with Apache, agreeing to consider their appeal.
